questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of stiffness and pain in multiple joints. The patient says that the fingers on both of her hands have become increasingly stiff and difficult to move over the past 8 months. During this time, she has also noticed that her nails break easily and look spotty. One year ago, she had a urinary tract infection that was treated with antibiotics. Her only medication is occasional ibuprofen for chronic back pain. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her vitals are within normal limits. A photograph of her right hand is shown. There are multiple, well-demarcated red plaques with silvery-white scales over the shins and back. Serum studies show a negative rheumatoid factor and ANA. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis causes polyarthritis, sacroiliitis, tendinopathy, dactylitis, and extra-articular symptoms such as skin lesions. While this patient presents with arthritis and dactylitis, polyarthritis in reactive arthritis usually involves the lower extremities, and skin lesions would present differently (hyperkeratinization of the palms and soles). The latency period of reactive arthritis is typically 1–4 weeks, but the urinary tract infection in this patient was one year ago.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's sexual history puts her at risk of syphilis, secondary syphilis is characterized by constitutional symptoms (generalized nontender lymphadenopathy, fever, fatigue) and a polymorphic rash that is typically reddish-brown or copper-colored. None of these features are present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Ankylosing spondylitis causes back pain but it does not typically affect the hands and fingers. Ankylosing spondylitis also does not cause any of the extra-articular symptoms seen in this patient. Furthermore, this condition more commonly affects men 20–30 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis causes oligoarthritis, which usually affects the hands, and is also present in this patient. However, the distal interphalangeal joints are typically spared, whereas the metacarpophalangeal joints are typically affected. Furthermore, rheumatoid factor is usually positive in rheumatoid arthritis, although it has a low specificity for the disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Arthritis-dermatitis syndrome is a potential manifestation of disseminated gonococcal infection, which has a classic triad of symptoms that includes arthralgias, tenosynovitis, and dermatitis. While the patient does present with arthralgias and her sexual history puts her at risk of infection, her skin lesions are not consistent with those in arthritis-dermatitis syndrome, she lacks fever, and the condition does not cause the dactylitis and nail changes seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Degenerative osteoarthritis typically affects the weight-bearing joints (knees, hips) first, not the hands and fingers. It also would not explain any of this patient's other symptoms, as osteoarthritis does not cause any extra-articular symptoms.

G) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can cause various symptoms, including rash and arthritis, as in this patient. However, the rash would typically be a malar rash (butterfly rash) with sparing of the nasolabial folds. Additionally, this patient has none of the other typical findings of SLE, such as fever, fatigue, photosensitivity, or Raynaud phenomenon.

H) CORRECT:

This patient meets many diagnostic criteria of the CASPAR classification for psoriatic arthritis, including skin psoriasis (plaques with silvery-white scales), psoriatic nail dystrophy, negative rheumatoid factor, and dactylitis. In contrast to rheumatoid arthritis, which also affects the hands, the metacarpophalangeal joint is usually not involved in psoriatic arthritis, although the distal interphalangeal joint is.

The pencil-in-cup deformity refers to periarticular erosion around the distal interphalangeal joint that gives the appearance of a pencil in a cup. It is classically associated with psoriatic arthritis but can also be found in patients with other conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis and reactive arthritis.
questions.hint: An x-ray of this patient's hand would likely show a pencil-in-cup deformity.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of multiple, dry, scaly lesions on his elbows. The lesions appeared 4 months ago and have progressively increased in size. They are itchy and bleed when he scratches them. There is no associated pain or discharge. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 6 years ago. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. Current medications include raltegravir, lamivudine, and abacavir. A photograph of the lesions is shown. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 470/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HPV-2 infection causes verruca vulgaris (common wart), which can appear as discrete, raised, scaly lesions on regions of microtrauma such as the dorsal surface of the elbow (pseudo-koebnerization). The incidence of verucca vulgaris is higher in patients with HIV infection. However, these lesions are usually papules (unlike the plaques seen here), are typically not itchy, and do not bleed easily on scratching. Moreover, the surface of these lesions would be made up of multiple, tiny, finger-like projections. In patients with severe verruca vulgaris (e.g., immunocompromised patients), many warts can coalesce to form larger plaque-like lesions. In such a scenario, however, multiple satellite lesions would be evident near the larger plaque.
Image Description:

Multiple whitish plaques and papules are visible on the distal end of the fingers. A larger hyperkeratotic plaque with a verrucous and scaly surface can be seen on the distal end of the right thumb.

Common warts are typically associated with HPV infection.

B) INCORRECT:

HHV-8 infection causes Kaposi sarcoma, which can manifest with rapidly growing plaques. Kaposi sarcoma is also associated with immunocompromised states (e.g., HIV infection) and the Koebner phenomenon may also be present. However, the plaques would be violaceous due to the vascular nature of the lesions.
Image Description:

The purple-bluish lesions, seen on the heel of this HIV-positive patient, are multiple Kaposi sarcoma. The lesion on the left side is elevated, while the other lesions are patches. The causative agent is HHV-8.

C) INCORRECT:

Malassezia furfur infection can cause seborrheic dermatitis, which would cause scaly, itchy patches. Seborrheic dermatitis also occurs more often and is more severe in HIV-infected patients. However, the lesions of seborrheic dermatitis usually occur on the scalp, cutaneous folds of the face (e.g., nasolabial crease), chest, axilla, or groin. Moreover, the lesions are often associated with mild inflammation and greasy skin, and would not appear as discrete, thick, or silvery-white as those seen here.
Image Description:

Erythema is visible on the cheeks, nasolabial folds, and chin. Overlying scaling is also present.

These findings are consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Infiltration of neoplastic T cells is seen in patients with cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, which is associated with immunocompromised states such as HIV infection and manifests with itchy, scaly plaques. However, the plaques would be pink, red, or brown rather than silvery-white, and the lesions are usually located over the chest, back, abdomen, and/or buttocks. Moreover, the course of the disease is slowly progressive and flat lesions would be present for a few years before the onset of plaques. Furthermore, cutaneous T-cell lymphoma primarily occurs in middle-aged and elderly patients.
Image Description:

Multiple partially confluent, sharply demarcated, erythematous, scaling plaques are visible on this patient's flank.

This appearance is suggestive of cutaneous lymphoma.

E) CORRECT:

In psoriatic lesions, basal keratinocytes hyperproliferate and rapidly progress through all the epidermal layers (over 4–5 days) without undergoing complete differentiation. This typically causes erythematous and/or scaly plaques (plaque psoriasis) to appear. The precise cause of this hyperproliferation is not understood, but a T-cell mediated process and cytokines such as interleukins and TNF-α are suspected to play a role. Other sites for psoriatic lesions include the scalp and back. In addition to skin changes, patients with psoriasis can have dystrophic nail changes (e.g., pitting, brittle nails, onycholysis), and/or arthralgia (psoriatic arthritis). Psoriasis is diagnosed based on clinical examination.

Mild psoriasis can be treated with emollients and topical preparations of steroids, vitamin D derivates (e.g., calcipotriene), coal tar, or retinoids. Moderate to severe forms of psoriasis can be treated with phototherapy and/or systemic immunosuppression (e.g., methotrexate, cyclosporine, etanercept, adalimumab, infliximab).

F) INCORRECT:

IgE-mediated hypersensitivity causes atopic dermatitis, which may result in pruritic skin lesions. However, atopic dermatitis is characterized by acute exacerbations with erythema, crusting, and/or excoriation. Symptom onset is generally during early childhood. The elbows and knees are commonly affected sites in atopic dermatitis, and hyperkeratotic skin may be seen in long-standing cases (due to lichenification). However, lichenified skin is usually hyperpigmented and not well-demarcated, in contrast to the well-demarcated, silvery lesions seen here.
Image Description:

Ill-defined, erythematous macules with excoriation (due to scratching) can be seen on the flexural surface of the knee.

G) INCORRECT:

Exfoliative skin inflammation is seen in erythroderma, which may result in pruritus and scaling. Patients with HIV infection may develop erythroderma as a result of Sezary syndrome or the use of certain NNRTIs. However, erythroderma has a hyperacute course. Moreover, the scaling would be fine and generalized, and, most importantly, preceded by erythema of > 90 % of the skin surface, increased skin temperature, and cutaneous edema.
Image Description:

Back of a 68-year-old patient showing generalized erythematosquamous skin.
questions.hint: The photograph shows well-demarcated plaques with silvery scaling. The morphology of the lesion, bleeding when superficial scales are removed (Auspitz sign), symmetrical involvement of both limbs, location of the lesion on the extensor surface, and the propensity of the lesion to occur on regions of microtrauma such as the elbows (Koebner phenomenon) indicate psoriasis. Both HIV infection and smoking are risk factors for psoriasis. Psoriatic lesions can be itchy because of local inflammation and/or skin irritation by psoriatic skin flakes.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a rash on the elbows for several months. A biopsy of the affected area shows a thinned stratum granulosum as well as retained nuclei and spongiotic clusters of neutrophils in the stratum corneum. This patient's skin findings are most likely associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy seen in up to ⅓ of patients with psoriasis. Apart from skin involvement, common findings in psoriatic arthritis include asymmetric arthritis, nail lesions, inflamed, sausage-like fingers (dactylitis), and pencil-in-cup deformity of the distal interphalangeal joints (DIPs) on x-ray.

B) INCORRECT:

Gliadin hypersensitivity is not associated with psoriasis but is characteristic of celiac disease, which is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis, an autoimmune blistering skin disorder. Unlike this patient's findings, skin biopsy in dermatitis herpetiformis shows subepidermal clefting and blistering with IgA deposition at dermal papillae.

C) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis C virus infection is not associated with psoriasis but is characteristic of lichen planus, a skin condition that can also manifest on the elbows. However, skin biopsy in lichen planus shows hypergranulosis rather than this patient's thinning of the stratum granulosum.

D) INCORRECT:

Hashimoto thyroiditis does not occur at higher rates in patients with psoriasis but is associated with other autoimmune conditions, including vitiligo. Vitiligo is characterized by depigmentation of the skin caused by destruction or dysfunction of melanocytes, which is inconsistent with this patient's findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Parkinson disease is not associated with psoriasis but does often occur in patients with seborrheic dermatitis. This inflammatory skin condition causes recurring itchy and/or burning flares that show erythematous, patchy scaling, or greasy yellow crust on examination, unlike this patient's presentation.

F) INCORRECT:

Insulin resistance (e.g., diabetes or Cushing syndrome) is not associated with psoriasis but is characteristic of acanthosis nigricans. However, acanthosis nigricans does not typically manifest on the elbows. Additionally, skin biopsy in acanthosis nigricans shows acanthosis.

Acanthosis nigricans is commonly due to an underlying malignancy (especially gastric cancer).
questions.hint: Thinning of the stratum granulosum, parakeratotic stratum corneum (retained nuclei), and clusters of neutrophils in the stratum corneum (Munro microabscesses) on this patient's skin biopsy are highly suggestive of psoriasis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 30-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of skin lesions on his elbows. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Physical examination shows skin lesions on bilateral elbows. A photograph of his right elbow is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's skin condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dapsone is the first-line treatment of choice for dermatitis herpetiformis (DH), which commonly manifests on extensor surfaces, similar to this patient's lesions. However, the lesions of DH are typically tense, grouped, pruritic, subepidermal vesicles (that mimic herpetic lesions). DH is usually strongly associated with celiac disease, which there is no reason to suspect in this patient. Dapsone is not used in the treatment of psoriasis.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

B) INCORRECT:

Terbinafine is used to treat dermatophyte infections such as tinea corporis, which manifests as round, erythematous plaques similar to this patient's lesions. However, dermatophyte infections are usually intensely pruritic and grow centrifugally before developing a central clearing and a scaly, raised border (ringworm appearance). The scale is typically flaky and thin, in contrast to this patient's thick scale. Bilateral involvement of the elbows is uncommon. Terbinafine is not used in the treatment of psoriasis.
Image Description:

An erythematous patch with mild scaling and central clearing is seen on the left wrist.

These features are characteristic of dermatophyte fungal infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Ketoconazole is used to treat fungal infections such as seborrheic dermatitis, which can manifest as scaly, erythematous plaques. More commonly, it causes greasy, yellow plaques. Seborrheic dermatitis predominantly affects areas with hair and oily skin such as the scalp, nasolabial folds, axillae, and groin, and does not typically affect the extremities. Ketoconazole is not used in the treatment of psoriasis.
Image Description:

Well-defined erythematous plaques are visible on the scalp.

This appearance is consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

D) CORRECT:

Calcipotriene, a vitamin D analog, is a topical therapy for the treatment of mild psoriasis. Although its exact mechanism of action is unclear, it activates the intracellular vitamin D receptor, a transcription factor that promotes keratinocyte differentiation and inhibits keratinocyte proliferation. Keratinocytes are characteristically hyperproliferative in plaque psoriasis. Vitamin D analogs are effective when used alone but are commonly used in combination therapy with topical corticosteroids.

E) INCORRECT:

Diphenhydramine and other histamine antagonists are used to treat allergic conditions such as urticaria and provide symptomatic relief of pruritus (e.g., in patients with atopic dermatitis). Atopic dermatitis typically manifests as pruritic, eczematous, and lichenified plaques on flexor surfaces of the extremities (in contrast to the extensor surface involvement common in psoriasis). Though psoriatic lesions can be pruritic, antihistaminic therapy would not address the underlying etiology of pruritus and would not be an appropriate first-line choice for initial treatment of this patient.
Image Description:

Ill-defined, erythematous macules with excoriation (due to scratching) can be seen on the flexural surface of the knee.
questions.hint: The pictured lesions are well-demarcated, erythematous, rounded plaques with silvery-white scale on the extensor surfaces of the arm. These findings are typical of mild plaque psoriasis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 2-week history of new pruritic plaques on the scalp and extensor surfaces of the elbows and knees. Ten years ago, she was diagnosed with psoriasis. Her only medication is topical calcipotriene. Physical examination shows well-demarcated, symmetrical, erythematous plaques with silvery scale. There is pitting of the nails on all fingers. Therapy with a high-potency topical medication that inhibits NF-κB and phospholipase A2 is begun. Long-term use of this agent is most likely to result in which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic, systemic corticosteroid use is associated with increased risk of developing cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma but not dysplastic nevi or melanoma. Topical corticosteroid use is not known to increase the risk of any skin cancer type.
Image Description:

An asymmetric, pigmented lesion with irregular borders and color variegation is visible over the left little finger.

These are characteristic features of an atypical nevus.

B) INCORRECT:

Petechiae are non-blanchable, vascular, pinpoint, red macules that can develop on the skin in patients with thrombocytopenia. Chronic topical corticosteroid use does not cause petechiae, but it is associated with an increased fragility of blood vessels which can cause larger hemorrhages presenting as purpura or ecchymoses.
Image Description:

Hand of a 30-year-old patient showing non-blanching palpable purpura and petechiae.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic topical corticosteroid increases (not decreases!) production of sebum on the skin, which can cause an acneiform eruption characterized by monomorphic inflammatory papules and pustules. This type of eruption resolves after discontinuation of corticosteroid use.
Image Description:

Multiple pustules and erythematous papules are visible on the back of a young woman who had received high-dose methylprednisolone therapy for one week.

D) CORRECT:

Chronic use of topical corticosteroids causes dermal collagen loss, which manifests as skin atrophy (skin thinning) and stretch marks. Skin thinning is the most common side effect of topical corticosteroid use and often causes the skin to appear translucent, making any underlying vasculature more visible. Longer duration of use, treatment with higher-strength corticosteroids (e.g., clobetasol), and use under occlusion increase the risk of adverse effects. Patients should receive directions on when to stop topical corticosteroid therapy to prevent this adverse effect.

Corticosteroids bind to intracellular glucocorticoid receptors, forming a complex that translocates into the nucleus, where it interacts with specific DNA sequences. The complex activates IκB, which inhibits the function of NF-κB, a transcription factor that normally promotes expression of numerous pro-inflammatory cytokine genes. It also inhibits production of arachidonic acid derivatives by inhibiting phospholipase A2.
Image Description:

The skin appears thin and translucent and the veins are unusually prominent. Purpura is visible in several places.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic corticosteroid use can cause hypertrichosis, particularly of the vellus hairs (e.g., on the upper lip among women). However, this adverse effect is usually limited to the area of corticosteroid application and is thus unlikely to occur on the upper lip in this patient with psoriatic lesions on the elbows and knees.
questions.hint: Corticosteroids exhibit an anti-inflammatory effect by inhibiting NF-κB and phospholipase A2. This patient has started to use a high-potency topical corticosteroid for a relapse of plaque psoriasis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because she is embarrassed about the appearance of her nails. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She appears well. A photograph of the nails is shown. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Flesh-colored papules in the lumbosacral region
Holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Silvery plaques on the extensor surfaces are the characteristic skin finding seen in psoriasis, which can also cause nail pitting. Nail pitting results from focal areas of abnormal keratinization of the nail matrix due to increased proliferation of keratinocytes. As is the case here, the pits are usually deep, irregular, and randomly distributed.

Other psoriasis-associated nail changes include the oil drop sign, brittle nails, and onycholysis.
Image Description:

Extensor (dorsal) surface of the right forearm

Multiple well-demarcated, partially confluent, erythematous plaques with silver-white scaling are visible.

These patches are characteristic of plaque psoriasis, which typically occurs on extensor surfaces of the body.

B) INCORRECT:

Flesh-colored papules in the lumbosacral region (Shagreen patches) would be consistent with tuberous sclerosis, which can also manifest with periungual fibromas. This patient's deformed and brittle nails, however, are distinct from periungual fibromas, which appear as smooth, flesh-colored nodules.

C) INCORRECT:

Erosions of the dental enamel are typically seen in patients with bulimia. These patients can present with dorsal hand calluses, which are known as the Russell sign. While brittle nails may be seen, bulimia is not associated with the nail pitting seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Pallor of the conjunctival mucosa is a common feature in patients with anemia (e.g., due to iron deficiency anemia). Iron deficiency anemia can also cause nail changes, including brittle nails. However, patients with iron deficiency anemia typically present with koilonychia, which is not seen in this patient. Furthermore, anemia significant enough to cause nail changes would also be likely to cause additional symptoms such as fatigue, which is not present here.
Image Description:

Fingers (A) and thumb (B) of the right hand of a 22-year-old female patient presenting with weakness, weight loss, and reduced appetite

The nails are centrally concave and bend upwards distally, resulting in a characteristic spoon shape.

The most common cause of koilonychia is iron deficiency anemia, as was the case here.

E) INCORRECT:

A holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border would be suggestive of ventricular septal defect (VSD). While patients with VSD may show nail clubbing, nail pitting would be unexpected. Furthermore, it would be unusual for a VSD to go undiagnosed for so long, as they are usually present at birth.
questions.hint: The photograph shows small, round depressions in the nail (pitting), which is seen in psoriasis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of nail changes. She reports that multiple fingernails have a rough texture and are brittle. Seven months ago, she was diagnosed with social anxiety disorder, and treatment with sertraline and propranolol as needed was initiated. She has no history of other illnesses. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 65 kg (143 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows small round depressions in multiple nails with distal separation of the nail from the nail bed of both middle fingers. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Plaques with silvery scale on the extensor surfaces
Holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border
Oval-shaped, hypopigmented macules on the trunk
Painful subcutaneous nodules on the palms and soles

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pallor of the conjunctival mucosa is a common finding in patients with iron deficiency anemia, which can cause brittle nails. However, this condition is not associated with nail pitting or onycholysis. In addition, this patient does not have other manifestations of iron deficiency anemia, such as koilonychia, fatigue, tachycardia, angular cheilitis, and atrophic glossitis.

B) CORRECT:

Plaques with silvery scale on the extensor surfaces are characteristic skin findings in patients with psoriasis, which is associated with nail changes in ∼ 50% of cases. These nail changes are caused by abnormal keratinization of the nail matrix and include brittle nails, nail pitting, and onycholysis, all of which are seen in this patient. Several drugs can trigger or exacerbate psoriasis, including beta-blockers (such as propranolol, which this woman takes), lithium, and antimalarial drugs (e.g., chloroquine).

Another psoriasis-associated nail change is the oil drop sign, which is characterized by well-circumscribed, yellow-reddish discoloration of the nail.
Image Description:

The middle finger shows numerous superficial, round depressions (nail pits; examples indicated by arrowheads) caused by deficient keratinization. Both the ring and the middle finger show distal separation of the nail plate (onycholysis; green overlay). The index finger appears mostly normal.

Nail pitting and onycholysis are typical features of psoriasis with nail involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

A holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border can be heard in patients with a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Most VSDs close spontaneously during childhood but can persist into adulthood. If severe enough to cause pulmonary hypertension (Eisenmenger syndrome), VSDs can lead to nail clubbing. However, it is not associated with brittle nails, nail pitting, or onycholysis.
Image Description:

The nails are enlarged and rounded with increased convexity (Hippocratic nails). There is club-shaped swelling of the distal phalanges in all fingers.

These findings indicate an underlying pathology causing chronic hypoxemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Erosions of the dental enamel can be seen in patients with bulimia, which can manifest with brittle nails and normal BMI. However, nail pitting and onycholysis are not associated with this condition. In addition, this patient does not have other manifestations of bulimia, including dorsal hand calluses (Russell sign), gastritis, dental caries, and bilateral parotid gland swelling.

E) INCORRECT:

Oval-shaped, hypopigmented macules scattered on the trunk (ash-leaf spots) are associated with tuberous sclerosis, which can manifest with nail changes. However, the nail changes typically seen in patients with tuberous sclerosis are ungual fibromas, which are erythematous papules that grow under (subungually) or around the nails (periungually). In addition, tuberous sclerosis usually manifests in early childhood with seizures, cognitive deficits, and multiple benign hamartomas, none of which is seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Painful subcutaneous nodules on the palms and soles (Osler nodes) can be seen in patients with infective endocarditis (IE), which can manifest with splinter hemorrhages underneath the nail plate. However, IE is not associated with brittle nails, nail pitting, or onycholysis. In addition, patients with IE are typically ill-appearing (fever, chills, tachycardia) with an acute onset of symptoms.
Image Description:

Multiple bluish-black longitudinal lesions (resembling splinters) can be seen underneath the fingernail. These lesions do not blanch on pressure.
questions.hint: This patient's nail findings show pitting and onycholysis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of skin lesions on the knees and lower legs. He is worried that the lesions are getting progressively larger and reports that some are mildly pruritic. He has no history of previous illness and takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. He drinks three to five beers daily. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 98 kg (216 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the right knee is shown. The skin lesions comprise less than 5% of the total body surface area. The most appropriate initial treatment should include which of the following agents?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical dapsone is the first-line treatment for dermatitis herpetiformis, which most commonly develops on extensor surfaces. However, this condition typically manifests with tense, grouped, subepidermal vesicles (which mimic herpetic lesions). In addition, this condition is strongly associated with celiac disease, for which there is no reason to suspect in this patient. Dapsone is not used to treat psoriasis.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

B) INCORRECT:

Selenium sulfide is a topical medication that is used to treat seborrheic dermatitis and tinea versicolor. Seborrheic dermatitis can manifest with scaly, erythematous plaques. However, the associated scale is typically greasy, and this condition predominantly affects areas with hair and/or oily skin (e.g., scalp and face). Tinea versicolor typically manifests with variably-pigmented macules, patches, and thin, scaly plaques on the upper trunk. Selenium sulfide is not used to treat psoriasis.
Image Description:

There are multiple round, well-demarcated, confluent, light-brown macules visible on this patient's back.

This finding indicates pityriasis versicolor, caused by Malassezia species.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical terbinafine is used to treat cutaneous fungal infections, including dermatophyte infections (e.g., tinea corporis) and tinea versicolor. Dermatophyte infections typically manifest with round, erythematous plaques. However, these lesions are usually scaly, intensely pruritic, and grow centrifugally before developing a central clearing. Tinea versicolor typically manifests with variably-pigmented macules, patches, and thin, scaly plaques on the upper trunk. Terbinafine is not used to treat psoriasis.
Image Description:

A round, well demarcated erythematous lesion with central scaling is visible. The border is raised with several pustules visible.

These features are characteristic of tinea corporis.

D) CORRECT:

Mild plaque psoriasis is typically treated with topical medications and moisturizers. The first-line topical medication is corticosteroids, which are often combined with topical vitamin D derivates (e.g., calcipotriene), tar preparations, anthralin, or keratolytics (e.g., tazarotene). For areas of the skin that are susceptible to corticosteroid-induced atrophy (e.g., intertriginous and facial areas), topical calcineurin inhibitors can be used. Patients who have more extensive skin involvement (> 5% of total body surface area) or decreased quality of life (e.g., functional impairment, psychosocial distress) may additionally benefit from UVB phototherapy or systemic treatment.

Systemic medications used to treat psoriasis include methotrexate, retinoids (e.g., acitretin), cyclosporine, and biologic agents (e.g., TNF-α inhibitors, IL-17 inhibitors, IL-23 inhibitors).

E) INCORRECT:

Ustekinumab can be used to treat severe psoriasis (e.g., disease with extensive skin involvement, disease that causes functional impairment or psychosocial distress). Although effective, ustekinumab is not an appropriate choice for the initial treatment of this patient with mild disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Infliximab can be used to treat severe psoriasis (e.g., disease with extensive skin involvement, disease that causes functional impairment or psychosocial distress). Although effective, infliximab is not an appropriate first-line choice for the initial treatment of this patient with localized disease.
questions.hint: The photograph shows well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery-white scales, which are typical of plaque psoriasis. This patient's involvement of less than 5% of total body surface area indicates that he has mild disease.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman presents with a worsening flare of arthritis that has been attributed to psoriatic arthritis. In the 15 years since her initial diagnosis, she has received nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, topical glucocorticoids, and then, as her symptoms worsened, sulfasalazine and eventually subcutaneous methotrexate. She initially responded well to methotrexate 25 mg weekly with daily folic acid, but both her skin disease and joint disease have worsened again.
Physical examination reveals swelling and tenderness of the distal and proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints on both hands, an erythematous and tender first digit on the right foot, a large effusion of the left knee, and diffuse, scaly erythematous plaques on the extensor surfaces of the knees and elbows. Synovial fluid aspirated from the left knee has a leukocyte count of 11,000 per mm3 . Crystal examination, Gram stain, and culture of synovial fluid are all negative.
A foot radiograph is obtained (figure).
What is the most appropriate long-term treatment option for this patient?

choices.text: Increase subcutaneous methotrexate to 50 mg weekly
Add oral hydroxychloroquine 200 mg twice daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phototherapy will not improve arthritis symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

The patient’s dermatologic and joint findings are indicative of psoriatic arthritis. The examination and joint aspirate indicate an active inflammatory arthritis, given that the synovial fluid leukocyte count is >2000 per mm3 .

The radiograph demonstrates soft-tissue swelling that is not confined to the distribution of the joint. The interphalangeal joint space is narrow, and there are subchondral cysts and marginal erosions. There is new periosteal bone formation and endosteal bone formation (the so-called ivory phalanx). These findings and the asymmetric distribution are typical of psoriatic arthritis.

Tumor necrosis factor inhibitors (adalimumab, etanercept, infliximab, certolizumab, golimumab, and now biosimilars of some of these products) are likely to improve symptoms in patients with psoriatic arthritis that is refractory to the recommended maximum dose of methotrexate (25 mg weekly). Additional biologic agents with proven efficacy in psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis include secukinumab and ixekizumab (both interleukin-17a inhibitors) and ustekinumab (an interleukin-12/23 inhibitor). Additional small-molecule (nonbiologic) agents that may be used in patients with psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis include tofacitinib (a Janus kinase inhibitor), leflunomide, and cyclosporine.

Key learning point: The most appropriate long-term treatment for a psoriatic arthritis that is refractory to nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug therapy and to methotrexate monotherapy is continued methotrexate therapy plus a biologic agent.

C) INCORRECT:

Further increasing the methotrexate dose is rarely of much additional benefit and raises the risk of methotrexate-related hepatic and bone-marrow toxicities.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydroxychloroquine is unlikely to benefit psoriatic arthritis and may exacerbate psoriasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Prednisone may alleviate joint symptoms in the short term but is not an ideal maintenance therapy, particularly at a dose of 20 mg daily, because the side effects of long-term use outweigh the benefits. “Rebound” exacerbation of psoriasis may also occur when prednisone is tapered off. This can include severe forms of psoriasis, such as pustular psoriasis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a history of alcohol use disorder presents with a chronic, diffuse rash covering more than 50% of his body-surface area. Physical examination reveals multiple, well-demarcated, discrete, and coalescing inflammatory plaques covering a large part of the skin surface (figure). There is significant swelling of the second and third digits of the left hand and point tenderness at the distal interphalangeal joints. A radiograph of the left hand reveals pencil-in-cup deformity.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate long-term therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although an oral glucocorticoid can treat psoriatic arthritis, high doses are not recommended as part of long-term therapy because of the many adverse effects of chronic glucocorticoid use. Furthermore, in patients with psoriasis, rapidly tapering a glucocorticoid carries a risk for rebound flares of plaque-type, erythrodermic, or pustular psoriasis. Intra-articular injection of a glucocorticoid can be a very effective treatment for a patient with psoriatic arthritis of one joint (e.g., the knee).

B) CORRECT:

The classic features of psoriatic arthritis of the hands include pain and swelling due to underlying inflammation and osteolysis of the bone. The pencil-in-cup deformity is a common radiographic finding in psoriatic arthritis and is the result of osteolysis and bone resorption with telescoping of the digits.

Of the options listed, a tumor necrosis factor inhibitor is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s psoriasis and concomitant psoriatic arthritis. Additional available options include calcineurin inhibitors (e.g., cyclosporine, tacrolimus), phosphodiesterase type 4 inhibitors (e.g., apremilast), interleukin-12/23 monoclonal antibodies (e.g., ustekinumab), and interleukin-17 inhibitors (e.g., secukinumab, ixekizumab).

Oral and subcutaneous methotrexate can be effective in a subset of patients with psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis. However, methotrexate can be hepatotoxic, and this patient’s alcohol use disorder precludes the use of methotrexate.

Key learning point: The most appropriate long-term treatment for a patient with alcohol use disorder who presents with psoriatic arthritis is a tumor necrosis factor inhibitor (such as etanercept, adalimumab, infliximab, certolizumab, golimumab, or a biosimilar of one of these products).

C) INCORRECT:

Oral and subcutaneous methotrexate can be effective in a subset of patients with psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis. However, methotrexate can be hepatotoxic, and this patient’s alcohol use disorder precludes the use of methotrexate.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoid ointment is not a treatment for psoriatic arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Phototherapy is not a treatment for psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 35-year-old man presents with a rash on his elbows and knees that is occasionally very itchy and seems to get worse when he scratches it. He appears well and has normal vital signs. His examination is unremarkable except for his skin findings. There are round, erythematous, well-marginated plaques covered with silvery-white scale on the elbows and knees (figure 1) and distinct 1-mm focal indentations and distal yellow discoloration in several of his nails (figure 2). He has no history of joint pain or swelling.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Prescribe a mid- to high-potency topical glucocorticoid
Recommend using selenium sulfide wash once daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate and other systemic therapies may be used under the guidance of a dermatologist to treat severe psoriasis but are not indicated for localized disease in the absence of arthritis.

B) CORRECT:

Psoriasis is a common skin disorder affecting approximately 2% to 3% of the United States population. Psoriasis lesions are typically round, erythematous, well-marginated plaques covered with silvery-white scale. When the patient scratches the scale, it may spread due to the trauma (Koebner phenomenon). Common sites of involvement include the scalp, elbows, knees, and gluteal crease; however, psoriasis can occur anywhere on the body.

Nail pitting, although not specific to psoriasis, is a helpful diagnostic clue in the presence of typical skin lesions. Nail involvement, including pitting, yellowish discoloration, and lifting of the nail plate up off the nail bed, may occur before, at the same time as, or after a diagnosis of psoriasis. Severe nail disease is a predictor of having or developing psoriatic arthritis, but the presence of nail disease does not necessarily indicate arthritis.

Psoriasis can affect patients’ perceptions of themselves and lead to significant psychosocial disability. Therefore, treatment is generally recommended. The most appropriate initial treatment for a patient with mild-to-moderate plaque psoriasis affecting the elbows and knees is a mid- or high-potency topical glucocorticoid (such as 0.1% triamcinolone or fluocinonide, respectively) applied twice daily.

Key learning point: The presence of round, erythematous, well-marginated plaques with silvery-white scale on the knees and elbows is most consistent with a diagnosis of psoriasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Selenium sulfide is a topical preparation (lotion, shampoo) used to treat fungal skin infections such as tinea versicolor and dandruff.

D) INCORRECT:

Mupirocin is a topical antibiotic; it is not indicated for psoriasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Benzoyl peroxide is a first-line treatment for acne but has no role in the treatment of psoriasis.

questions.text:

Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this child?

Prescribe a mid- to high-potency topical glucocorticoid

D) INCORRECT:

Benzoyl peroxide is a first-line treatment for acne but has no role in the treatment of psoriasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Mupirocin is a topical antibiotic; it is not indicated for psoriasis.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman in the second trimester of her first pregnancy presents with worsening psoriasis. She is bothered most by diffuse, scaly silver patches and plaques on her arms, neck, and trunk, which have proliferated during the past 4 to 6 weeks. She applies betamethasone cream to the areas twice daily, which was effective during previous episodes of localized psoriasis, but she has seen little improvement recently, and new lesions continue to develop. She reports no joint pain or swelling. She has no other medical problems, and her pregnancy is otherwise uncomplicated.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Switch betamethasone to another high-potency topical glucocorticoid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Switching from betamethasone to another high-potency topical glucocorticoid (such as fluocinonide) is unlikely to yield improvement, given the rapid development of new lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

Tumor necrosis factor inhibitors, such as etanercept (pregnancy category B), are considered third-line options for women whose psoriasis does not improve with phototherapy.

C) CORRECT:

Psoriasis may fluctuate during pregnancy in unpredictable ways; it improves in some women and worsens in others. Few if any randomized controlled trial data are available to guide treatment. Topical glucocorticoids are the first-line treatment for psoriasis. For women with severe widespread disease who do not respond to this treatment, narrow-band ultraviolet B (UVB) phototherapy is an appropriate choice because it appears to be neither teratogenic nor immunosuppressive. Folic acid supplementation should be considered in any pregnant woman being treated with UVB phototherapy because folic acid levels have been shown to decline in this setting.

Key learning point: Second-line treatment for a pregnant woman who has worsening moderate-to-severe psoriasis that has not responded to a topical glucocorticoid is narrow-band ultraviolet B phototherapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic therapies such as cyclosporine (pregnancy category C) should be avoided during pregnancy unless absolutely necessary, and methotrexate (pregnancy category X) is contraindicated during pregnancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic therapies such as cyclosporine (pregnancy category C) should be avoided during pregnancy unless absolutely necessary, and methotrexate (pregnancy category X) is contraindicated during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the office because of stiffness and pain in multiple joints. The patient says that the fingers on both of her hands have become increasingly stiff and difficult to move over the past 8 months. During this time, she has also noticed that her nails break easily and look spotty. One year ago, she had a urinary tract infection that was treated with antibiotics. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her vitals are within normal limits. A photograph of her right hand is shown. There are multiple, well-demarcated red plaques with silvery-white scales over the shins and back. Serum studies show a negative rheumatoid factor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis causes polyarthritis, sacroiliitis, tendinopathy, dactylitis, and extra-articular symptoms such as skin lesions. While this patient presents with arthritis and dactylitis, polyarthritis in reactive arthritis usually involves the lower extremities, and skin lesions would present differently (hyperkeratinization of the palms and soles). The latency period of reactive arthritis is typically 1–4 weeks, but the urinary tract infection in this patient was one year ago.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's sexual history puts her at risk of syphilis, secondary syphilis is characterized by constitutional symptoms (generalized nontender lymphadenopathy, fever, fatigue) and a polymorphic rash that is typically reddish-brown or copper-colored. None of these features are present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis causes oligoarthritis, which usually affects the hands, and is also present in this patient. However, the distal interphalangeal joints are typically spared, whereas the metacarpophalangeal joints are typically affected. Furthermore, rheumatoid factor is usually positive in rheumatoid arthritis, although it has a low specificity for the disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Arthritis-dermatitis syndrome is a potential manifestation of disseminated gonococcal infection, which has a classic triad of symptoms that includes arthralgias, tenosynovitis, and dermatitis. While the patient does present with arthralgias and her sexual history puts her at risk of infection, her skin lesions are not consistent with those in arthritis-dermatitis syndrome, she lacks fever, and the condition does not cause the dactylitis and nail changes seen in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

This patient meets many diagnostic criteria of the CASPAR classification for psoriatic arthritis, including skin psoriasis (plaques with silvery-white scales), psoriatic nail dystrophy, negative rheumatoid factor, and dactylitis. In contrast to rheumatoid arthritis, which also affects the hands, the metacarpophalangeal joint is usually not involved in psoriatic arthritis, although the distal interphalangeal joint is.

The pencil-in-cup deformity refers to periarticular erosion around the distal interphalangeal joint that gives the appearance of a pencil in a cup. It is classically associated with psoriatic arthritis but can also be found in patients with other conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis and reactive arthritis.
questions.hint: An x-ray of this patient's hand would likely show a pencil-in-cup deformity.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the office because she is embarrassed about the appearance of her nails. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She appears well. A photograph of the nails is shown. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Flesh-colored papules in the lumbosacral region
Holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Silvery plaques on the extensor surfaces are the characteristic skin finding seen in psoriasis, which can also cause nail pitting. Nail pitting results from focal areas of abnormal keratinization of the nail matrix due to increased proliferation of keratinocytes. As is the case here, the pits are usually deep, irregular, and randomly distributed.

Other psoriasis-associated nail changes include the oil drop sign, brittle nails, and onycholysis.
Image Description:

Extensor (dorsal) surface of the right forearm

Multiple well-demarcated, partially confluent, erythematous plaques with silver-white scaling are visible.

These patches are characteristic of plaque psoriasis, which typically occurs on extensor surfaces of the body.

B) INCORRECT:

Flesh-colored papules in the lumbosacral region (Shagreen patches) would be consistent with tuberous sclerosis, which can also manifest with periungual fibromas. This patient's deformed and brittle nails, however, are distinct from periungual fibromas, which appear as smooth, flesh-colored nodules.

C) INCORRECT:

Erosions of the dental enamel are typically seen in patients with bulimia. These patients can present with dorsal hand calluses, which are known as the Russell sign. While brittle nails may be seen, bulimia is not associated with the nail pitting seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Pallor of the conjunctival mucosa is a common feature in patients with anemia (e.g., due to iron deficiency anemia). Iron deficiency anemia can also cause nail changes, including brittle nails. However, patients with iron deficiency anemia typically present with koilonychia, which is not seen in this patient. Furthermore, anemia significant enough to cause nail changes would also be likely to cause additional symptoms such as fatigue, which is not present here.
Image Description:

Fingers (A) and thumb (B) of the right hand of a 22-year-old female patient presenting with weakness, weight loss, and reduced appetite

The nails are centrally concave and bend upwards distally, resulting in a characteristic spoon shape.

The most common cause of koilonychia is iron deficiency anemia, as was the case here.

E) INCORRECT:

A holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border would be suggestive of ventricular septal defect (VSD). While patients with VSD may show nail clubbing, nail pitting would be unexpected. Furthermore, it would be unusual for a VSD to go undiagnosed for so long, as they are usually present at birth.
questions.hint: The photograph shows small, round depressions in the nail (pitting), which is seen in psoriasis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents with a three-month history of mildly pruritic, scaly plaques on her extensor surfaces. She has tried intermittent low-potency topical corticosteroids with partial response and topical emollients with partial improvement. She denies any personal or family history of similar lesions and has no joint pain. Examination shows well-demarcated, erythematous lesions with minimal scaling. The differential includes psoriasis and other chronic dermatoses. She expresses concern about the exact diagnosis.
What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: KOH scraping to rule out fungal infection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

KOH scraping is used to diagnose dermatophyte infections, which present with ring-like lesions and central clearing. The patient's well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with minimal scaling are more indicative of a chronic inflammatory dermatosis, not a fungal infection.

B) INCORRECT:

High-potency topical corticosteroids are used for confirmed inflammatory skin conditions like psoriasis. However, in this patient, diagnostic uncertainty exists, and further confirmation is needed before escalating therapy. Using high-potency steroids without a definitive diagnosis risks obscuring clinical features and causing adverse effects.

C) CORRECT:

A punch biopsy provides a full-thickness skin sample, crucial for differentiating psoriasis from other chronic dermatoses when clinical findings are ambiguous. Histopathology in psoriasis typically shows parakeratosis, Munro microabscesses, thinning of the granular layer, and irregular acanthosis. These features confirm the diagnosis and guide appropriate management.

Key learning point: Psoriasis is usually diagnosed clinically based on characteristic skin lesions, but a biopsy may be required for confirmation in atypical or uncertain cases.

D) INCORRECT:

Narrow-band UVB therapy is effective for moderate to severe psoriasis but requires a confirmed diagnosis. The patient's presentation and partial response to low-potency corticosteroids suggest diagnostic uncertainty, necessitating further evaluation before initiating this treatment.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents with persistent swelling and pain in his left big toe for seven months to the Outpatient Clinic. He has a longstanding history of plaque psoriasis. He was initially diagnosed with gout and started on allopurinol, but his symptoms have shown minimal improvement. He has scaly lesions on his elbows, and his toe remains tender and slightly warm. Vital signs are within normal limits. He has full range of motion despite discomfort (see lab result and reports).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Uric acid
360 μmol/L
200 - 410 μmol/L



Arthrocentesis: No monosodium urate crystals
Radiographs: Periarticular erosions and new bone formation

What is the most likely cause of his persistent toe pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic tophaceous gout involves hyperuricemia and deposition of monosodium urate crystals, typically showing needle-shaped crystals on joint aspiration and punched-out erosions on radiographs. This patient has normal serum uric acid levels and no crystals on arthrocentesis. The radiographic findings of periarticular erosions with new bone formation are not typical of gout, indicating a different etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis typically presents with joint-space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, and osteophyte formation on imaging, not periarticular erosions with new bone formation. The presence of tenderness and warmth, along with a history of psoriasis, suggests an inflammatory process rather than degenerative changes.

C) CORRECT:

Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, characterized by periarticular erosions and new bone formation on radiographs. This patient has a history of plaque psoriasis and scaly lesions on the elbows, which are clinical indicators of psoriatic arthritis. The absence of monosodium urate crystals on arthrocentesis and normal serum uric acid levels differentiate it from gout. The maintained range of motion and the specific radiographic findings support the diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis, particularly given the involvement of the big toe, a common site.

Key learning point: In patients with psoriasis and joint pain, psoriatic arthritis should be considered, especially if the pain persists despite treatment for gout.

D) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis usually presents as symmetric polyarthritis with joint space narrowing and marginal erosions, not new bone formation. The isolated involvement of the big toe and the patient's history of psoriasis suggest psoriatic arthritis. The radiographic findings and lack of symmetric joint involvement further argue against rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to your clinic with multiple, dry, scaly lesions on his elbows. The lesions began 4 months ago and have gradually increased in size. He reports that they are itchy and bleed when scratched, but there is no pain or discharge. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 6 years ago. He has a 10-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. His current medications are raltegravir, lamivudine, and abacavir. A photograph of the lesions is provided. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 470 cells/μL (500–2000). Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exfoliative skin inflammation is seen in erythroderma, which may result in pruritus and scaling. Patients with HIV infection may develop erythroderma as a result of Sezary syndrome or the use of certain NNRTIs. However, erythroderma has a hyperacute course. Moreover, the scaling would be fine and generalized, and, most importantly, preceded by erythema of > 90 % of the skin surface, increased skin temperature, and cutaneous edema.

B) INCORRECT:

Infiltration of neoplastic T cells is seen in patients with cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, which is associated with immunocompromised states such as HIV infection and manifests with itchy, scaly plaques. However, the plaques would be pink, red, or brown rather than silvery-white, and the lesions are usually located over the chest, back, abdomen, and/or buttocks. Moreover, the course of the disease is slowly progressive and flat lesions would be present for a few years before the onset of plaques. Furthermore, cutaneous T-cell lymphoma primarily occurs in middle-aged and elderly patients.

C) CORRECT:

In psoriatic lesions, basal keratinocytes hyperproliferate and rapidly progress through all the epidermal layers (over 4–5 days) without undergoing complete differentiation. This typically causes erythematous and/or scaly plaques (plaque psoriasis) to appear. The precise cause of this hyperproliferation is not understood, but a T-cell mediated process and cytokines such as interleukins and TNF-α are suspected to play a role. Other sites for psoriatic lesions include the scalp and back. In addition to skin changes, patients with psoriasis can have dystrophic nail changes (e.g., pitting, brittle nails, onycholysis), and/or arthralgia (psoriatic arthritis). Psoriasis is diagnosed based on clinical examination.

Mild psoriasis can be treated with emollients and topical preparations of steroids, vitamin D derivates (e.g., calcipotriene), coal tar, or retinoids. Moderate to severe forms of psoriasis can be treated with phototherapy and/or systemic immunosuppression (e.g., methotrexate, cyclosporine, etanercept, adalimumab, infliximab).

Key learning point: Psoriasis is characterized by T cell–mediated increased keratinocyte proliferation, leading to well-demarcated, scaly plaques on the skin.

D) INCORRECT:

Malassezia furfur infection can cause seborrheic dermatitis, which would cause scaly, itchy patches. Seborrheic dermatitis also occurs more often and is more severe in HIV-infected patients. However, the lesions of seborrheic dermatitis usually occur on the scalp, cutaneous folds of the face (e.g., nasolabial crease), chest, axilla, or groin. Moreover, the lesions are often associated with mild inflammation and greasy skin, and would not appear as discrete, thick, or silvery-white as those seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

HHV-8 infection causes Kaposi sarcoma, which can manifest with rapidly growing plaques. Kaposi sarcoma is also associated with immunocompromised states (e.g., HIV infection) and the Koebner phenomenon may also be present. However, the plaques would be violaceous due to the vascular nature of the lesions.
questions.hint: The photograph shows well-demarcated plaques with silvery scaling. The morphology of the lesion, bleeding when superficial scales are removed (Auspitz sign), symmetrical involvement of both limbs, location of the lesion on the extensor surface, and the propensity of the lesion to occur on regions of microtrauma such as the elbows (Koebner phenomenon) indicate psoriasis. Both HIV infection and smoking are risk factors for psoriasis. Psoriatic lesions can be itchy because of local inflammation and/or skin irritation by psoriatic skin flakes.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 5-month history of nail changes. She reports that several fingernails have become rough and brittle. Seven months ago, she was diagnosed with social anxiety disorder and started on sertraline and propranolol as needed. She has no other medical history. She is 165 cm tall and weighs 65 kg; BMI is 24. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are small round depressions in multiple nails and distal separation of the nail from the nail bed on both middle fingers. Which one of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Plaques with silvery scale on the extensor surfaces.
Oval-shaped, hypopigmented macules on the trunk.
Holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erosions of the dental enamel can be seen in patients with bulimia, which can manifest with brittle nails and normal BMI. However, nail pitting and onycholysis are not associated with this condition. In addition, this patient does not have other manifestations of bulimia, including dorsal hand calluses (Russell sign), gastritis, dental caries, and bilateral parotid gland swelling.

B) CORRECT:

Plaques with silvery scale on the extensor surfaces are characteristic skin findings in patients with psoriasis, which is associated with nail changes in ∼ 50% of cases. These nail changes are caused by abnormal keratinization of the nail matrix and include brittle nails, nail pitting, and onycholysis, all of which are seen in this patient. Several drugs can trigger or exacerbate psoriasis, including beta-blockers (such as propranolol, which this woman takes), lithium, and antimalarial drugs (e.g., chloroquine).

Another psoriasis-associated nail change is the oil drop sign, which is characterized by well-circumscribed, yellow-reddish discoloration of the nail.

Key learning point: Psoriasis commonly causes nail pitting, onycholysis, and brittle nails, and is often associated with well-demarcated plaques with silvery scale on extensor surfaces.
Image Description:

The middle finger shows numerous superficial, round depressions (nail pits; examples indicated by arrowheads) caused by deficient keratinization. Both the ring and the middle finger show distal separation of the nail plate (onycholysis; green overlay). The index finger appears mostly normal.

Nail pitting and onycholysis are typical features of psoriasis with nail involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Pallor of the conjunctival mucosa is a common finding in patients with iron deficiency anemia, which can cause brittle nails. However, this condition is not associated with nail pitting or onycholysis. In addition, this patient does not have other manifestations of iron deficiency anemia, such as koilonychia, fatigue, tachycardia, angular cheilitis, and atrophic glossitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Oval-shaped, hypopigmented macules scattered on the trunk (ash-leaf spots) are associated with tuberous sclerosis, which can manifest with nail changes. However, the nail changes typically seen in patients with tuberous sclerosis are ungual fibromas, which are erythematous papules that grow under (subungually) or around the nails (periungually). In addition, tuberous sclerosis usually manifests in early childhood with seizures, cognitive deficits, and multiple benign hamartomas, none of which is seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

A holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border can be heard in patients with a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Most VSDs close spontaneously during childhood but can persist into adulthood. If severe enough to cause pulmonary hypertension (Eisenmenger syndrome), VSDs can lead to nail clubbing. However, it is not associated with brittle nails, nail pitting, or onycholysis.
questions.hint: This patient's nail findings show pitting and onycholysis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to your clinic with a rash on his elbows and knees that is occasionally very itchy and worsens with scratching. Vital signs are normal. Examination is unremarkable except for his skin findings. You observe round, erythematous, well-demarcated plaques with silvery-white scale on the elbows and knees (figure 1), as well as distinct 1-mm focal indentations and distal yellow discoloration in several nails (figure 2). He has no history of joint pain or swelling. Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Recommend using selenium sulfide wash once daily.
Prescribe a mid- to high-potency topical glucocorticoid.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Selenium sulfide is a topical preparation (lotion, shampoo) used to treat fungal skin infections such as tinea versicolor and dandruff.

B) CORRECT:

Psoriasis is a common skin disorder affecting approximately 2% to 3% of the United States population. Psoriasis lesions are typically round, erythematous, well-marginated plaques covered with silvery-white scale. When the patient scratches the scale, it may spread due to the trauma (Koebner phenomenon). Common sites of involvement include the scalp, elbows, knees, and gluteal crease; however, psoriasis can occur anywhere on the body.

Nail pitting, although not specific to psoriasis, is a helpful diagnostic clue in the presence of typical skin lesions. Nail involvement, including pitting, yellowish discoloration, and lifting of the nail plate up off the nail bed, may occur before, at the same time as, or after a diagnosis of psoriasis. Severe nail disease is a predictor of having or developing psoriatic arthritis, but the presence of nail disease does not necessarily indicate arthritis.

Psoriasis can affect patients’ perceptions of themselves and lead to significant psychosocial disability. Therefore, treatment is generally recommended. The most appropriate initial treatment for a patient with mild-to-moderate plaque psoriasis affecting the elbows and knees is a mid- or high-potency topical glucocorticoid (such as 0.1% triamcinolone or fluocinonide, respectively) applied twice daily.

Key learning point: The presence of round, erythematous, well-marginated plaques with silvery-white scale on the knees and elbows is most consistent with a diagnosis of psoriasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Benzoyl peroxide is a first-line treatment for acne but has no role in the treatment of psoriasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate and other systemic therapies may be used under the guidance of a dermatologist to treat severe psoriasis but are not indicated for localized disease in the absence of arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Mupirocin is a topical antibiotic; it is not indicated for psoriasis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to your clinic because she is concerned about the appearance of her nails. She has no history of serious illness and does not take any medications. A photograph of the nails is provided. Which one of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border.
Flesh-colored papules in the lumbosacral region.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pallor of the conjunctival mucosa is a common feature in patients with anemia (e.g., due to iron deficiency anemia). Iron deficiency anemia can also cause nail changes, including brittle nails. However, patients with iron deficiency anemia typically present with koilonychia, which is not seen in this patient. Furthermore, anemia significant enough to cause nail changes would also be likely to cause additional symptoms such as fatigue, which is not present here.

B) INCORRECT:

A holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border would be suggestive of ventricular septal defect (VSD). While patients with VSD may show nail clubbing, nail pitting would be unexpected. Furthermore, it would be unusual for a VSD to go undiagnosed for so long, as they are usually present at birth.

C) INCORRECT:

Flesh-colored papules in the lumbosacral region (Shagreen patches) would be consistent with tuberous sclerosis, which can also manifest with periungual fibromas. This patient's deformed and brittle nails, however, are distinct from periungual fibromas, which appear as smooth, flesh-colored nodules.

D) INCORRECT:

Erosions of the dental enamel are typically seen in patients with bulimia. These patients can present with dorsal hand calluses, which are known as the Russell sign. While brittle nails may be seen, bulimia is not associated with the nail pitting seen here.

E) CORRECT:

Silvery plaques on the extensor surfaces are the characteristic skin finding seen in psoriasis, which can also cause nail pitting. Nail pitting results from focal areas of abnormal keratinization of the nail matrix due to increased proliferation of keratinocytes. As is the case here, the pits are usually deep, irregular, and randomly distributed.

Other psoriasis-associated nail changes include the oil drop sign, brittle nails, and onycholysis.

Key learning point: Nail pitting is a classic finding in psoriasis, which also presents with silvery plaques on extensor surfaces and other nail changes like onycholysis and the oil drop sign.
Image Description:

Extensor (dorsal) surface of the right forearm

Multiple well-demarcated, partially confluent, erythematous plaques with silver-white scaling are visible.

These patches are characteristic of plaque psoriasis, which typically occurs on extensor surfaces of the body.
questions.hint: The photograph shows small, round depressions in the nail (pitting), which is seen in psoriasis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with 3 months of joint pain and intermittent swelling. He reports morning stiffness lasting about 45 minutes and pain in his right knee. Examination shows diffuse swelling of the right index finger and tenderness at several distal finger joints. He also has a scaly rash over both elbows. Vital signs are BP, 128/76; P, 96; R, 16; T, 37.2°C (99°F). Laboratory studies show WBC 8,600/mm³, ESR 35 mm/hr, and uric acid 5.1 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis is characterized by symmetric involvement of the small joints, particularly the MCP and PIP joints, while sparing the distal interphalangeal joints. The asymmetric distribution and distal joint findings in this patient are inconsistent with rheumatoid arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Gout usually manifests with acute, episodic attacks of severe monoarthritis, most often in the first metatarsophalangeal joint. Chronic distal finger arthritis is not typical. In addition, this patient’s uric acid level is within the normal range, making gout less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis causes asymmetric oligoarthritis, often involving the knee. However, reactive arthritis typically occurs following a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection. Also, distal interphalangeal joint involvement, dactylitis, and rash are not typically seen.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis can affect distal interphalangeal joints but typically causes pain that worsens with use. Morning stiffness is usually minimal in osteoarthritis. The presence of inflammatory features (e.g., prolonged morning stiffness, elevated ESR) and a rash makes osteoarthritis less likely.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – The combination of a chronic rash on extensor surfaces, dactylitis of the index finger, distal joint involvement, and findings consistent with inflammatory arthritis (e.g., prolonged morning stiffness, elevated ESR) is most consistent with psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient with a 5-year history of psoriasis presents with a 2-week history of progressive joint pain and swelling. Physical examination shows asymmetric involvement of the right second proximal interphalangeal joint and left ankle, and there is diffuse swelling of the left third digit. The patient reports morning stiffness lasting 45 minutes and denies fever, recent illness, or trauma. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein are elevated. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Refer to rheumatology for evaluation and treatment
Order rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Colchicine is primarily used for gout prophylaxis and treatment. The pattern of asymmetric oligoarthritis with dactylitis in a patient with established psoriasis is more consistent with psoriatic arthritis than with gout.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Asymmetric oligoarthritis with dactylitis in a patient with established psoriasis is consistent with psoriatic arthritis. Early rheumatologic consultation is essential for proper evaluation and treatment planning.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation strongly suggests psoriatic arthritis. Rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies are typically negative in psoriatic arthritis and do not change immediate management.

D) INCORRECT:

High-dose systemic corticosteroids are generally avoided in psoriatic arthritis due to the risk of precipitating a psoriatic flare upon discontinuation.

E) INCORRECT:

Initiating methotrexate therapy is inappropriate for an emergency physician. Rheumatology consultation is required before starting pharmacotherapy, and disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs require specialized monitoring that falls outside the scope of emergency medicine practice.
